Dear Ms. Klinski:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Please review the
enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In the event
that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager at 616-552-3662.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4127 Staff-to-resident ratio
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Description supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are not completing eye-on variable interval room checks in
real time.
Investigation DCWL received these allegations reported by Complainant on
9/20/23.
I contacted Complainant on 9/20/23 via telephone. He was hired
as a direct care worker at the facility in August 2023 and had not
decided if he would return to work or resign. Complainant said
2

when he worked with Staff 1 and 2, they did not check the youth’s
rooms during reflection time (13:45 – 14:30) so he had to do it.
I reviewed room check logs dated 9/1/23, 9/2/23, 9/7/23, 9/16/23
and 9/17/23 when Staff 1, Staff 2 and/or Complainant worked.
The logs showed room checks were completed during reflection
time.
I interviewed Staff 8 jointly with Government Worker. She has
worked at the facility for three months. To her knowledge, she
said staff perform eye on variable room checks when youths are in
their rooms unsupervised during “reflection time.”
I interviewed Supervisor jointly with Government Worker. She
said youths go into their rooms for bed on afternoon shift at 8pm.
and midnight shift starts at 10pm. Supervisor said she rounds the
pods and sometimes sees the staff performing their required eye-
on variable interval room checks. “When staff see me, they get up
right away to do checks,” she laughed. As a trainer Supervisor
said she understands and trains staff on the licensing rule
requiring eye-on variable interval checks.
I interviewed Director jointly with Government Worker. She has
been the director for one year. Director said her internal
monitoring process includes viewing video every other day of the
late afternoon and midnight shifts to assure staff are completing
their room checks at appropriate intervals.
At my request, for this specific investigation, Director spent time
on 9/26/23 viewing video of the afternoon and midnight shifts that
Staff 1 and/or 2 worked for the period of 9/1/23 – 9/18/23 and
reported that all room checks were completed.
I showed up on-site again on 10/27/23 and asked to see video of
Staff 1 and 2 completing room checks during the time frame
previously viewed by Director. I was informed Lincoln Center’s
video saves for 60 days. I was unable to view the video because
the facility was experiencing technical difficulty and all footage for
the month of September was missing, which was verified. As of
10/30/23 Director still was unable to recover the footage.
Government Worker had no findings.
Analysis Room check logs dated 9/1/23, 9/2/23, 9/7/23, 9/16/23 and
9/17/23 showed room checks were completed appropriately
during reflection time.
3

Director has an ongoing process of viewing video to assure staff
are completing eye on variable interval room checks. Based on
room check logs, and video footage viewed by Director, there was
no evidence the staff identified failed to perform variable interval
room checks in between 9/1/23 – 9/18/23.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to
Section requirements; staff qualifications.
Description (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff sleep during their shift and falsify room check
documentation.
Investigation Complainant said Staff 2 told him she sleeps when she works the
midnight shift, and that multiple other unidentified staff advised
him to work midnights so he can sleep. When Complainant
arrives for dayshift at 6am, he said he has found Staff 1 asleep.
Complainant said he has seen Staff 1, 2 and 3 completing their
room check documentation (pink sheets) before or after their
shifts, and not in real time.
I reviewed room check logs dated 9/1/23, 9/2/23, 9/7/23, 9/16/23
and 9/17/23 when Complainant, Staff 1, Staff 2 and/or Staff 3
worked. The documentation was completed appropriately and
there were no signs it was falsified.
Supervisor told me Director reviews the video regularly and
recently terminated Supervisor 2 for falsifying documents.
Director said her internal monitoring process includes viewing
video every other day of late afternoon and midnight shifts to
assure staff are alert and performing room checks. She said she
takes room checks seriously and recently terminated Supervisor 2
for prefilling his initials on room check sheets before the actual
room checks occurred.
For this specific investigation, at my request, Director viewed
video of the midnight shifts that Staff 1 and/or Staff 2 worked for
4

the period of 9/1/23 – 9/18/23 and attested that both staff were
alert throughout their shifts.
I showed up on-site again on 10/27/23 and asked to see video of
Staff 1 and 2 completing room checks during the time frame
previously viewed by Director. The facility was experiencing
technical difficulties, which was verified, and video footage was
unavailable for the month of September 2023. The footage was
still unavailable as of 10/30/23.
Government Worker had no findings.
Analysis The facility has an internal process of viewing video every other
day to assure staff are alert during their shift and performing room
checks. Based on room check logs and the video footage viewed
by Director, there is no evidence that Staff 1, 2 or 3 slept during
their shifts or falsified room check documents between 9/1/23 –
9/18/23.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation a) Staff violated policy by failing to search Youth T’s room or
person after he stabbed Staff 7 with a stolen pen on 9/18/23.
b) Staff violate policy by allowing youths to trade food on Pod G.
Investigation Allegation a):
On 9/18/23 Complainant said he and Staff 4 were working
afternoon shift on Pod F. Youth T ran up to him, grabbed a pen
from his shirt pocket and scratched him with it causing him to
bleed “slightly.” Complainant clarified the youth “scratched” him
with the pen, not “stabbed” him. Supervisor arrived, minimized
the incident and did not take the pen from the youth.
5

I attempted to interview Youth T jointly with Government Worker.
Youth T refused to be interviewed.
I interviewed Staff 4 via phone on 10/30/23. She has worked at
the facility for four months. Staff 4 said she saw Youth T take
Complainant’s pen from his shirt pocket. “He told me Youth T
scratched him with it and he was going to write him up.
Complainant got a bandage and showed me a dot of blood on his
arm.”
I asked Staff 4 if anyone searched or confiscated the pen from
Youth T. She did not know. “I believe we did it…I’m pretty sure
we took it…I don’t know. I probably didn’t get it.”
I interviewed Supervisor jointly with Government Worker. She has
worked at the facility over three years, is a trainer and supervises
the direct care staff on afternoon shift. During her shift,
Supervisor said she rounds all of the pods and shows support to
the staff.
On 9/18/23 Supervisor said she was called to the pod and
Complainant told her Youth T had taken his pen. He did not tell
her the youth scratched him with it. “I started to go get the pen
from Youth T, but Complainant told me ‘No, I don’t want Youth T
to be mad.’” Supervisor agreed to downplay the incident and
circle back to it later. “I came back later and built up a discussion
with Youth T to get the pen but was unsuccessful. I told Staff 4 to
make sure they searched the rooms during shower time (per
routine).”
I asked Supervisor if all room and person searches are
documented. She stated, “They (staff) don’t write it down, but
used to.” Supervisor said pens are not considered contraband per
se. Youth T, specifically, was not allowed a pen due to his level,
but some youths are allowed to have them.
Supervisor did not know if Complainant’s pen was ever recovered
from Youth T that night. She said she thought it was important to
honor Complainant’s request not to immediately and overtly
search for the pen as not to upset Youth T.
I reviewed the Resident Search Policy dated 7/29/13. It indicates
“Shift Supervisors must search each resident “when there is
reasonable basis to believe the resident possesses contraband.”
Items that are considered contraband were not listed in this policy.
6

On 10/24/23 I reviewed another untitled document that identifies
pens as contraband and indicates: “Possession of contraband is
prohibited. Any unauthorized items in your possession or in your
room will be considered contraband. Contraband includes any
item out of its designated area or any item that is prohibited to you
by program rules or treatment staff, such as but not limited to,
matches, lighters, cigarettes, food, pens, pencils, silverware,
weapons, combs, etc. Your room will be searched by staff on a
regular basis.”
It should be noted that Lincoln Center presently has a CAP in
progress for SIR 2023C0000484 which indicates staff will be
retrained to document all room searches by 9/30/23.
Allegation b):
Complainant said Supervisor informed him there is a policy that
states youths are not allowed to trade food/snacks yet Staff 1, 2
and 3 let youths trade food without imposing consequences.
Supervisor clarified that “no trading” between youths is a youth
rule, not a staff policy. Rather “trading” is a negative behavior that
may subject youths to consequences. She said she is aware that
staff do not always consequent youths for sharing or trading
snacks, but she does encourage them to enforce youth rules.
Additionally, Supervisor stated there is no policy that indicates
staff cannot give extra food to the youths at mealtime “but we
discourage it because of favoritism.”
Director also confirmed that staff are discouraged from giving
extra food at mealtime and while youth should not trade food, staff
have discretion on whether or not to impose consequences for
trading.
I reviewed the Discipline policy. It lists trading items such as
food/snacks as a misdemeanor rule violation. The policy says:
“Youth may be disciplined only in accordance with this policy.
Youth workers may impose disciplinary consequences for rule
violations at their own discretion. Youth workers may impose
disciplinary consequences for misdemeanor rule violations…only
with the review and approval of the Shift Supervisor.”
Other misdemeanor rule violations include gang activity, self-
harm, possession of contraband, defacing or misusing property,
stealing, threatening the safety of others, intimidating, bullying, not
7

completing disciplinary assignments, encouraging inappropriate
behavior in others, and continued negative behaviors that show a
lack of self-discipline.
Consequences for misdemeanor rule violations include a verbal
apology to the person or group for your self-defeating behavior
and lack of self-control, a written acceptable apology letter posted
in your pod for 3 days, a written Rational Thinking Paper
assignment related to your offense and one or two of the
following:
1) A loss of free time recreation privileges for 3 days
2) A loss of Merit Store purchases for 3 days.
3) Assignment to Thinking Table for 3 days to complete
additional Rational Thinking Reports. See definition in the
handbook.
4) Cleanup duties for 3 days.
5) Return to Level One Merit System Privileges for 5 days.
6) Restitution to the person(s) wronged by your behavior or
Restorative Justice Project community (pod).
Disciplinary records for misdemeanors will become part of your
permanent record (written and electronic) and may be used in
court reports and reports to your family and Community Case
Manager.”
For more information pertaining to a specific incident involving one
youth allegedly being bullied into giving another youth his food,
see concurrent SIR 2023C0000787 by Consultant 2.
Government Worker had no findings.
Analysis Allegation a): Supervisor was aware that Youth T stole a pen
from Complainant and was not allowed to have a pen. Supervisor
did not search for or attempt to confiscate the pen which was
considered contraband for Youth T due to his level. Failing to
search Youth T for known contraband was a violation of the
Resident Search Policy. (Violation established)
Allegation b): While staff are discouraged from doing it, there is
no policy that states they cannot give youth extra food at
mealtime.
The Discipline Policy indicates staff may consequent youths for
trading at their discretion. If Staff 1, 2 or 3 did give extra food
and/or failed to consequent youths for trading, it is not a policy
violation. (Violation not established)
8

CONSULTATION
In terms of staff enforcing rules, imposing consequences and
documenting it, the facility would benefit from developing clearer
guidelines and expectations for staff to promote consistency.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation a) Complainant believes Youth J is cognitively impaired.
Complainant heard a rumor that Youth J was gang raped in her
room by unidentified youths in August 2023.
b) Youths fought on 9/6/23 and it is unknown how or if staff
intervened.
c) A youth is bullying other youths and taking their snacks. It is
unknown if staff are aware.
Investigation Allegation a):
A social work contact in MISACWIS intake #104669391 indicated
Facility Manager was contacted on 9/20/23 by centralized intake
and said Youth J was at another facility prior to being admitted to
Lincoln Cener. Facility Manager reported Youth J is assigned
one-to-one staffing at Lincoln Center and does not interact with
peers. He denied Youth J was raped at Lincoln Center and did
not know any additional details regarding an alleged rape.
I spoke with Government Worker 2. She said she did a well-being
check of Youth J on 9/20/23 and Youth J refused to talk to her.
I interviewed Director jointly with Government Worker on 9/21/23.
She said Youth J is transgender female and uses she/her
pronouns. Director said there are no reports of Youth J being
raped at Lincoln Center, but she believes something may have
9

happened to the youth prior to admission. Director said Youth J
could not have been raped at Lincoln Center because since she
arrived, she has been on one-to-one staff supervision, isolates in
her room, refuses to come out for meals or education, and refuses
to socialize with peers. Director further indicated that Youth J
would not come to the visiting room to be interviewed today. In
her experience, when adults question her, Youth J remains silent
and extends her middle finger.
Government Worker went to Youth J’s room to interview the
youth. Youth J remained silent and refused to talk.
Allegation b):
I interviewed Youth B jointly with Government Worker. He said he
tried to calm down a peer who was upset and the peer punched
him in the nose. “Then I hit him three times in the face. Staff 3, 8
and 9 got between and tried to separate us…I didn’t see the nurse
that day because my nose didn’t hurt then. The next day I saw
the nurse and went to the hospital…I feel the staff tried to stop it. I
commend them.”
Staff 8 said two youths were escalated. Staff 3 verbally
intervened but was unsuccessful in preventing a physical
altercation. Two youths started fighting and somehow Youth B got
involved. “I stood in the middle and tried to break it up. I got hit in
the face and called security.”
I interviewed Staff 3 via phone on 10/24/23. He has worked at the
facility for ten months and has previous work experience at
another child caring institution. Staff 3 recalled the fight started
when Youth B verbally intervened with Youth Q while Youth Q
was on top of the shower refusing to go to his room. “I asked
Youth Q to come down. Staff 9 tried to calm Youth B. Youth Q
and B kept bickering. Youth Q jumped off the shower and hit
Youth B in the face. Youth B got hits in, and his nose bled. Me
and Staff 8 stepped in between and separated Youths B and Q.
Then other staff arrived to assist.”
I interviewed Staff 9 via phone on 10/24/23. She has worked at
the facility for three months. Staff 9 recalled being in the control
room and hearing commotion. “I sprang into action immediately.
Youths B and Q were brawling on the floor. I scooped Youth B up
lifting him away from Youth Q and got in between him and Youth
Q. Youth B’s nose was bleeding. I gave him a paper towel and
used verbal interventions to calm him down.”
10

I interviewed Youth Q at the facility on 10/27/23 regarding the fight
on 9/06/23. He said he jumped down from on top of the shower
and fought with Youth B. “Staff 3 broke it up. Staff 8 got him.
We’re all good now.” Youth Q denied that staff fail to intervene
when youths fight.
On 10/27/23 I viewed video of the fight in the dayroom on Pod G.
It showed Youth Q aggressively approaching and hitting Youth B.
Staff 3 and 8 struggled to physically separate the youths. Then
Youth A rushes in behind Youth B and pulls him away from Youth
Q.
Allegation c):
This allegation that a youth is bullying other youths and taking
their snacks is addressed in concurrent SIR 2023C0000787 by
Consultant 2.
Government Worker had no findings.
Analysis Allegation a): There is no evidence Youth T was raped at Lincoln
Center.
Allegation b): There is no evidence staff failed to intervene in the
fight between Youth B and Youth Q on 9/6/23.
Allegation c): This allegation is addressed in concurrent SIR
2023C0000787 by Consultant 2.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (2) The following restraints are strictly prohibited:
(g) Peer-on-peer discipline or utilizing the assistance of another
youth to implement a restraint.
Violation Potential Rule of statute violation.
Type
Allegation On 9/6/23 Youth B physically intervened to break up a fight
between other youths. Peer on peer discipline is prohibited.
11

Investigation Youth B said he tried to calm down a peer who was upset and the
peer punched him in the nose. “Then I hit him three times in the
face. Staff 3, 8 and 9 got between and tried to separate us…I
didn’t see the nurse that day because my nose didn’t hurt then.
The next day I saw the nurse and went to the hospital…I feel the
staff tried to stop it. I commend them.”
I asked Youth B if the staff at Lincoln Center allow or encourage
peer on peer discipline. He stated, “No. I got consequences for
trying to calm my peer and got another consequence before that
for putting people in a hold. Supervisor tells us do not restrain
other kids, but we don’t listen.”
Staff 8 said two youths were escalated. Staff 3 verbally
intervened but was not successful in preventing a physical
altercation. Two youths started fighting and somehow Youth B got
involved. She said staff do not allow or encourage youth to
discipline or physically manage other youth.
Staff 3 said the fight started when Youth B verbally intervened with
Youth Q when he refused to go to his room and a fight ensued.
Staff 3 denied Youth B tried to break up the fight, but rather he
participated in it.
Staff 9 recalled being in the control room and hearing a fight
taking place. “I sprang into action immediately. Youths B and Q
were brawling on the floor.” Staff 9 said Youth B was actively
fighting and not trying to break it up.
Youth Q denied that staff allow or encourage youth to physically
intervene in fights or to restrain other youth.
On 10/27/23 I viewed video of the fight that happened in the Pod
G dayroom on 9/18/23. It should be noted this video was available
as it was saved due there being a fight. It showed Youth Q
aggressively approaching and hitting Youth B. Staff 3 and 8
struggle to physically separate the youths. Then apparently out of
his own volition, Youth A rushes in behind Youth B and pulls him
away from Youth Q. There was no indication that Staff
encouraged or allowed Youth A to physically intervene in the fight.
Government Worker 1 had no findings.
Analysis Youth B said Supervisor directs youths not to physically intervene
or restrain other youths, but the youths do not always follow
directions. Video shows Youth A pulled Youth B away from Youth
12

Q of his own volition. There is no evidence the facility supports
peer on peer restraint or solicited assistance from Youth B or
Youth A to physically intervene in the fight.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and a corrective action plan is required.
